Yield Curve Slope Signal

Yield curve slope signal: tracking recession risk and monetary stance via curve shape.

As of Unknown

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Yield Curve Slope signal is currently in a Flat/Neutral regime, with a composite value of 0.644203 as of 2025-12-31 (1).
  • This indicates a transition from previous inversion towards a steepening trend.
  • Conviction Band: Medium, Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence, Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The current state is driven by positive robust z-scores for both the 10Y-2Y spread (0.735227) and the 10Y-3M spread (0.553179) as of 2025-12-31 (1).
  • The composite has shown consistent momentum away from deeply inverted territory since late 2024, now approaching the 0.75 threshold for a Steepening regime.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A significant decline in the 10Y-2Y and 10Y-3M spreads, leading to the composite falling below -0.75 and re-entering an Inverted regime, would reverse this interpretation (1).

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: The yield curve remains in a Flat/Neutral regime, potentially oscillating near the steepening threshold as policy outlooks evolve.
  • Upside secondary: A sustained move of the composite above 0.75 would signal a Steepening regime, likely reflecting clear policy easing or improving economic growth expectations (1).
  • Downside residual: A renewed, deep inversion (composite below -0.75) would signal increasing restrictive policy concerns or heightened recession risks (1).

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months). Yield curve signals are forward-looking indicators of economic cycles, with inversions historically preceding recessions by 6-18 months (1).
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: High. This signal provides robust, historically significant insights into macro regime transitions (1).

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs on liquidity, growth, and pricing dimensions, reflecting monetary policy stance and future economic expectations.
  • The current Flat/Neutral state, transitioning from Inverted, suggests a pivot from late-cycle or contractionary concerns towards potential mid-cycle stabilization or re-acceleration.
  • A steepening curve typically aligns with accommodative monetary conditions (2) and improving growth indicators like Capex Intent (3) or Housing Lead (4).

Data & References:

  • U.S. Treasury Yield Curve Signal (1): YC_Composite at 0.644203 and YC_Regime as Flat/Neutral, last observed 2025-12-31.
  • The 10Y-2Y spread (0.71) and 10Y-3M spread (0.51), with their respective robust z-scores, are most influential (1).
  • Additional public datasets: The effective federal funds rate to contextualize the short end, and market-implied term premiums for deeper structural analysis.
